algorithms.name: byte-lowercase
algorithms.html: To byte-lowercase a byte sequence, increase each byte it contains, in the range 0x41 (A) to 0x5A (Z), inclusive, by 0x20.

algorithms.name: byte-uppercase
algorithms.html: To byte-uppercase a byte sequence, subtract each byte it contains, in the range 0x61 (a) to 0x7A (z), inclusive, by 0x20.

algorithms.name: byte sequence/prefix
algorithms.html: A byte sequence potentialPrefix is a prefix of a byte sequence input if the following steps return true:

steps.html: Let i be 0.
While true:
If i is greater than or equal to potentialPrefix’s length, then return true.
If i is greater than or equal to input’s length, then return false.
Let potentialPrefixByte be the ith byte of potentialPrefix.
Let inputByte be the ith byte of input.
Return false if potentialPrefixByte is not inputByte.
Set i to i + 1.

algorithms.name: byte less than
algorithms.html: A byte sequence a is byte less than a byte sequence b if the following steps return true:

steps.html: If b is a prefix of a, then return false.
If a is a prefix of b, then return true.
Let n be the smallest index such that the nth byte of a is different from the nth byte of b. (There has to be such an index, since neither byte sequence is a prefix of the other.)
If the nth byte of a is less than the nth byte of b, then return true.
Return false.

algorithms.name: isomorphic decode
algorithms.html: To isomorphic decode a byte sequence input, return a string whose code point length is equal to input’s length and whose code points have the same values as the values of input’s bytes, in the same order.

algorithms.name: string/convert
algorithms.html: To convert a string into a scalar value string, replace any surrogates with U+FFFD (�).

algorithms.name: code unit prefix
algorithms.html: A string potentialPrefix is a code unit prefix of a string input if the following steps return true:

steps.html: Let i be 0.
While true:
If i is greater than or equal to potentialPrefix’s length, then return true.
If i is greater than or equal to input’s length, then return false.
Let potentialPrefixCodeUnit be the ith code unit of potentialPrefix.
Let inputCodeUnit be the ith code unit of input.
Return false if potentialPrefixCodeUnit is not inputCodeUnit.
Set i to i + 1.

algorithms.name: code unit suffix
algorithms.html: A string potentialSuffix is a code unit suffix of a string input if the following steps return true:

steps.html: Let i be 1.
While true:
Let potentialSuffixIndex be potentialSuffix’s length − i.
Let inputIndex be input’s length − i.
If potentialSuffixIndex is less than 0, then return true.
If inputIndex is less than 0, then return false.
Let potentialSuffixCodeUnit be the potentialSuffixIndexth code unit of potentialSuffix.
Let inputCodeUnit be the inputIndexth code unit of input.
Return false if potentialSuffixCodeUnit is not inputCodeUnit.
Set i to i + 1.

algorithms.name: code unit less than
algorithms.html: A string a is code unit less than a string b if the following steps return true:

steps.html: If b is a code unit prefix of a, then return false.
If a is a code unit prefix of b, then return true.
Let n be the smallest index such that the nth code unit of a is different from the nth code unit of b. (There has to be such an index, since neither string is a prefix of the other.)
If the nth code unit of a is less than the nth code unit of b, then return true.
Return false.

algorithms.name: code unit substring
algorithms.html: The code unit substring from start with length length within a string string is determined as follows:

steps.html: Assert: start and length are nonnegative.
Assert: start + length is less than or equal to string’s length.
Let result be the empty string.
For each i in the range from start to start + length, exclusive: append the ith code unit of string to result.
Return result.

algorithms.name: code point substring
algorithms.html: The code point substring within a string string from start with length length is determined as follows:

steps.html: Assert: start and length are nonnegative.
Assert: start + length is less than or equal to string’s code point length.
Let result be the empty string.
For each i in the range from start to start + length, exclusive: append the ith code point of string to result.
Return result.

algorithms.name: isomorphic encode
algorithms.html: To isomorphic encode an isomorphic string input: return a byte sequence whose length is equal to input’s code point length and whose bytes have the same values as the values of input’s code points, in the same order.

algorithms.name: ASCII lowercase
algorithms.html: To ASCII lowercase a string, replace all ASCII upper alphas in the string with their corresponding code point in ASCII lower alpha.

algorithms.name: ASCII uppercase
algorithms.html: To ASCII uppercase a string, replace all ASCII lower alphas in the string with their corresponding code point in ASCII upper alpha.

algorithms.name: ASCII encode
algorithms.html: To ASCII encode an ASCII string input: return the isomorphic encoding of input.

algorithms.name: ASCII decode
algorithms.html: To ASCII decode a byte sequence input, run these steps:

steps.html: Assert: all bytes in input are ASCII bytes.
Return the isomorphic decoding of input.

algorithms.name: strip newlines
algorithms.html: To strip newlines from a string, remove any U+000A LF and U+000D CR code points from the string.

algorithms.name: normalize newlines
algorithms.html: To normalize newlines in a string, replace every U+000D CR U+000A LF code point pair with a single U+000A LF code point, and then replace every remaining U+000D CR code point with a U+000A LF code point.

algorithms.name: strip leading and trailing ASCII whitespace
algorithms.html: To strip leading and trailing ASCII whitespace from a string, remove all ASCII whitespace that are at the start or the end of the string.

algorithms.name: strip and collapse ASCII whitespace
algorithms.html: To strip and collapse ASCII whitespace in a string, replace any sequence of one or more consecutive code points that are ASCII whitespace in the string with a single U+0020 SPACE code point, and then remove any leading and trailing ASCII whitespace from that string.

algorithms.name: collect a sequence of code points
algorithms.html: To collect a sequence of code points meeting a condition condition from a string input, given a position variable position tracking the position of the calling algorithm within input:

steps.html: Let result be the empty string.
While position doesn’t point past the end of input and the code point at position within input meets the condition condition:
Append that code point to the end of result.
Advance position by 1.
Return result.

algorithms.name: skip ASCII whitespace
algorithms.html: To skip ASCII whitespace within a string input given a position variable position, collect a sequence of code points that are ASCII whitespace from input given position. The collected code points are not used, but position is still updated.

algorithms.name: strictly split
algorithms.html: To strictly split a string input on a particular delimiter code point delimiter:

steps.html: Let position be a position variable for input, initially pointing at the start of input.
Let tokens be a list of strings, initially empty.
Let token be the result of collecting a sequence of code points that are not equal to delimiter from input, given position.
Append token to tokens.
While <var>position</var> is not past the end of <var>input</var>:
Assert: the code point at position within input is delimiter.
Advance position by 1.
Let token be the result of collecting a sequence of code points that are not equal to delimiter from input, given position.
Append token to tokens.
Return tokens.

algorithms.name: split on ASCII whitespace
algorithms.html: To split a string input on ASCII whitespace:

steps.html: Let position be a position variable for input, initially pointing at the start of input.
Let tokens be a list of strings, initially empty.
Skip ASCII whitespace within input given position.
While <var>position</var> is not past the end of <var>input</var>:
Let token be the result of collecting a sequence of code points that are not ASCII whitespace from input, given position.
Append token to tokens.
Skip ASCII whitespace within input given position.
Return tokens.

algorithms.name: split on commas
algorithms.html: To split a string input on commas:

steps.html: Let position be a position variable for input, initially pointing at the start of input.
Let tokens be a list of strings, initially empty.
While <var>position</var> is not past the end of <var>input</var>:
Let token be the result of collecting a sequence of code points that are not U+002C (,) from input, given position.
Strip leading and trailing ASCII whitespace from token.
Append token to tokens.
If <var>position</var> is not past the end of <var>input</var>, then:
Assert: the code point at position within input is U+002C (,).
Advance position by 1.
Return tokens.

algorithms.name: string/concatenate
algorithms.html: To concatenate a list of strings list, using an optional separator string separator, run these steps:

steps.html: If list is empty, then return the empty string.
If separator is not given, then set separator to the empty string.
Return a string whose contents are list’s items, in order, separated from each other by separator.

algorithms.name: list/append
algorithms.html: To append to a list that is not an ordered set is to add the given item to the end of the list.

algorithms.name: list/extend
algorithms.html: To extend a list A with a list B, for each item of B, append item to A.

algorithms.name: list/prepend
algorithms.html: To prepend to a list that is not an ordered set is to add the given item to the beginning of the list.

algorithms.name: list/replace
algorithms.html: To replace within a list that is not an ordered set is to replace all items from the list that match a given condition with the given item, or do nothing if none do.

algorithms.name: list/insert
algorithms.html: To insert an item into a list before an index is to add the given item to the list between the given index − 1 and the given index. If the given index is 0, then prepend the given item to the list.

algorithms.name: list/remove
algorithms.html: To remove zero or more items from a list is to remove all items from the list that match a given condition, or do nothing if none do.

algorithms.name: list/empty
algorithms.html: To empty a list is to remove all of its items.

algorithms.name: list/get the indices
algorithms.html: To get the indices of a list, return the range from 0 to the list’s size, exclusive.

algorithms.name: list/iterate
algorithms.html: To iterate over a list, performing a set of steps on each item in order, use phrasing of the form "For each item of list", and then operate on item in the subsequent prose.

algorithms.name: list/clone
algorithms.html: To clone a list list is to create a new list clone, of the same designation, and, for each item of list, append item to clone, so that clone contains the same items, in the same order as list.

algorithms.name: list/sort in ascending order
algorithms.html: To sort in ascending order a list list, with a less than algorithm lessThanAlgo, is to create a new list sorted, containing the same items as list but sorted so that according to lessThanAlgo, each item is less than the one following it, if any. For items that sort the same (i.e., for which lessThanAlgo returns false for both comparisons), their relative order in sorted must be the same as it was in list.

algorithms.name: list/sort in descending order
algorithms.html: To sort in descending order a list list, with a less than algorithm lessThanAlgo, is to create a new list sorted, containing the same items as list but sorted so that according to lessThanAlgo, each item is less than the one preceding it, if any. For items that sort the same (i.e., for which lessThanAlgo returns false for both comparisons), their relative order in sorted must be the same as it was in list.

algorithms.name: stack/push
algorithms.html: To push onto a stack is to append to it.

algorithms.name: stack/pop
algorithms.html: To pop from a stack: if the stack is not empty, then remove its last item and return it; otherwise, return nothing.

algorithms.name: stack/peek
algorithms.html: To peek into a stack: if the stack is not empty, then return its last item; otherwise, return nothing.

algorithms.name: queue/enqueue
algorithms.html: To enqueue in a queue is to append to it.

algorithms.name: queue/dequeue
algorithms.html: To dequeue from a queue is to remove its first item and return it, if the queue is not empty, or to return nothing if it is.

algorithms.name: set/append
algorithms.html: To append to an ordered set: if the set contains the given item, then do nothing; otherwise, perform the normal list append operation.

algorithms.name: set/prepend
algorithms.html: To prepend to an ordered set: if the set contains the given item, then do nothing; otherwise, perform the normal list prepend operation.

algorithms.name: set/replace
algorithms.html: To replace within an ordered set set, given item and replacement: if set contains item or replacement, then replace the first instance of either with replacement and remove all other instances.

algorithms.name: map/get
algorithms.html: To get the value of an entry in an ordered map map given a key key:

steps.html: Assert: map contains key.
Return the value of the entry in map whose key is key.

algorithms.name: map/set
algorithms.html: To set the value of an entry in an ordered map to a given value is to update the value of any existing entry if the map contains an entry with the given key, or if none such exists, to add a new entry with the given key/value to the end of the map. We can also denote this by saying, for an ordered map map, key key, and value value, "set map[key] to value".

algorithms.name: map/remove
algorithms.html: To remove an entry from an ordered map is to remove all entries from the map that match a given condition, or do nothing if none do. If the condition is having a certain key, then we can also denote this by saying, for an ordered map map and key key, "remove map[key]".

algorithms.name: map/clear
algorithms.html: To clear an ordered map is to remove all entries from the map.

algorithms.name: map/getting the keys
algorithms.html: To get the keys of an ordered map, return a new ordered set whose items are each of the keys in the map’s entries.

algorithms.name: map/getting the values
algorithms.html: To get the values of an ordered map, return a new list whose items are each of the values in the map’s entries.

algorithms.name: map/iterate
algorithms.html: To iterate over an ordered map, performing a set of steps on each entry in order, use phrasing of the form "For each key → value of map", and then operate on key and value in the subsequent prose.

algorithms.name: map/clone
algorithms.html: To clone an ordered map map is to create a new ordered map clone, and, for each key → value of map, set clone[key] to value.

algorithms.name: map/sort in ascending order
algorithms.html: To sort in ascending order a map map, with a less than algorithm lessThanAlgo, is to create a new map sorted, containing the same entries as map but sorted so that according to lessThanAlgo, each entry is less than the one following it, if any. For entries that sort the same (i.e., for which lessThanAlgo returns false for both comparisons), their relative order in sorted must be the same as it was in map.

algorithms.name: map/sort in descending order
algorithms.html: To sort in descending order a map map, with a less than algorithm lessThanAlgo, is to create a new map sorted, containing the same entries as map but sorted so that according to lessThanAlgo, each entry is less than the one preceding it, if any. For entries that sort the same (i.e., for which lessThanAlgo returns false for both comparisons), their relative order in sorted must be the same as it was in map.

algorithms.name: parse a JSON string to a JavaScript value
algorithms.html: To parse a JSON string to a JavaScript value, given a string string:

steps.html: Return ? Call(%JSON.parse%, undefined, « string »).

algorithms.name: parse JSON bytes to a JavaScript value
algorithms.html: To parse JSON bytes to a JavaScript value, given a byte sequence bytes:

steps.html: Let string be the result of running UTF-8 decode on bytes. [ENCODING]
Return the result of parsing a JSON string to a JavaScript value given string.

algorithms.name: serialize a JavaScript value to a JSON string
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export="" id="serialize-a-javascript-value-to-a-json-string" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">serialize a JavaScript value to a JSON string</dfn>, given a JavaScript value <var>value</var>:

steps.html: Let result be ? Call(%JSON.stringify%, undefined, « value »).
If result is undefined, then throw a TypeError.
Assert: result is a string.
Return result.

algorithms.name: serialize a JavaScript value to JSON bytes
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export="" id="serialize-a-javascript-value-to-json-bytes" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">serialize a JavaScript value to JSON bytes</dfn>, given a JavaScript value <var>value</var>:

steps.html: Let string be the result of serializing a JavaScript value to a JSON string given value.
Return the result of running UTF-8 encode on string. [ENCODING]

algorithms.name: parse a JSON string to an Infra value
algorithms.html: To parse a JSON string to an Infra value, given a string string:

steps.html: Let jsValue be ? Call(%JSON.parse%, undefined, « string »).
Return the result of converting a JSON-derived JavaScript value to an Infra value, given jsValue.

algorithms.name: parse JSON bytes to an Infra value
algorithms.html: To parse JSON bytes to an Infra value, given a byte sequence bytes:

steps.html: Let string be the result of running UTF-8 decode on bytes. [ENCODING]
Return the result of parsing a JSON string to an Infra value given string.

algorithms.name: convert a JSON-derived JavaScript value to an Infra value
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport="" id="convert-a-json-derived-javascript-value-to-an-infra-value" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">convert a JSON-derived JavaScript value to an Infra value</dfn>, given a JavaScript value <var>jsValue</var>:

steps.html: If jsValue is null, jsValue is a Boolean, jsValue is a String, or jsValue is a Number, then return jsValue.
If IsArray(jsValue) is true, then:
Let result be an empty list.
Let length be ! ToLength(! Get(jsValue, "length")).
For each index of the range 0 to length − 1, inclusive:
Let indexName be ! ToString(index).
Let jsValueAtIndex be ! Get(jsValue, indexName).
Let infraValueAtIndex be the result of converting a JSON-derived JavaScript value to an Infra value, given jsValueAtIndex.
Append infraValueAtIndex to result.
Return result.
Let result be an empty ordered map.
For each key of ! jsValue.[[OwnPropertyKeys]]():
Let jsValueAtKey be ! Get(jsValue, key).
Let infraValueAtKey be the result of converting a JSON-derived JavaScript value to an Infra value, given jsValueAtKey.
Set result[key] to infraValueAtKey.
Return result.

algorithms.name: serialize an Infra value to a JSON string
algorithms.html: To serialize an Infra value to a JSON string, given a string, boolean, number, null, list, or string-keyed map value:

steps.html: Let jsValue be the result of converting an Infra value to a JSON-compatible JavaScript value, given value.
Return ! Call(%JSON.stringify%, undefined, « jsValue »).

algorithms.name: serialize an Infra value to JSON bytes
algorithms.html: To serialize an Infra value to JSON bytes, given a string, boolean, number, null, list, or string-keyed map value:

steps.html: Let string be the result of serializing an Infra value to a JSON string, given value.
Return the result of running UTF-8 encode on string. [ENCODING]

algorithms.name: convert an Infra value to a JSON-compatible JavaScript value
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export="" id="convert-an-infra-value-to-a-json-compatible-javascript-value" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">convert an Infra value to a JSON-compatible JavaScript value</dfn>, given <var>value</var>:

steps.html: If value is a string, boolean, number, or null, then return value.
If value is a list, then:
Let jsValue be ! ArrayCreate(0).
Let i be 0.
For each listItem of value:
Let listItemJSValue be the result of converting an Infra value to a JSON-compatible JavaScript value, given listItem.
Perform ! CreateDataPropertyOrThrow(jsValue, ! ToString(i), listItemJSValue).
Set i to i + 1.
Return jsValue.
Assert: value is a map.
Let jsValue be ! OrdinaryObjectCreate(null).
For each mapKey → mapValue of value:
Assert: mapKey is a string.
Let mapValueJSValue be the result of converting an Infra value to a JSON-compatible JavaScript value, given mapValue.
Perform ! CreateDataPropertyOrThrow(jsValue, mapKey, mapValueJSValue).
Return jsValue.

algorithms.name: forgiving-base64 encode
algorithms.html: To forgiving-base64 encode given a byte sequence data, apply the base64 algorithm defined in section 4 of RFC 4648 to data and return the result. [RFC4648]

algorithms.name: forgiving-base64 decode
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export="" id="forgiving-base64-decode" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">forgiving-base64 decode</dfn> given a string <var>data</var>, run these steps:

steps.html: Remove all ASCII whitespace from data.
If data’s code point length divides by 4 leaving no remainder, then:
If data ends with one or two U+003D (=) code points, then remove them from data.
If data’s code point length divides by 4 leaving a remainder of 1, then return failure.

If data contains a code point that is not one of

  • U+002B (+)
  • U+002F (/)
  • ASCII alphanumeric

then return failure.
Let output be an empty byte sequence.
Let buffer be an empty buffer that can have bits appended to it.
Let position be a position variable for data, initially pointing at the start of data.
While <var>position</var> does not point past the end of <var>data</var>:
Find the code point pointed to by position in the second column of Table 1: The Base 64 Alphabet of RFC 4648. Let n be the number given in the first cell of the same row. [RFC4648]
Append the six bits corresponding to n, most significant bit first, to buffer.
If buffer has accumulated 24 bits, interpret them as three 8-bit big-endian numbers. Append three bytes with values equal to those numbers to output, in the same order, and then empty buffer.
Advance position by 1.

If buffer is not empty, it contains either 12 or 18 bits. If it contains 12 bits, then discard the last four and interpret the remaining eight as an 8-bit big-endian number. If it contains 18 bits, then discard the last two and interpret the remaining 16 as two 8-bit big-endian numbers. Append the one or two bytes with values equal to those one or two numbers to output, in the same order.
Return output.
